stem: The nurse in a psychiatric unit is reviewing the clinical trends for three clients on antipsychotic therapy. Based on the documentation in the Psychiatric Symptom Flowsheet, match each assessment finding to the appropriate adverse reaction.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 34y/o male on Haloperidol. He is unable to sit still and is constantly pacing the unit. Reports feeling 'restless in my skin'. 
Patient B: 29y/o female on Fluphenazine. Her neck is twisted to the side and her tongue is protruding. She appears highly distressed. 
Patient C: 50y/o male on Risperidone. He presents with a high fever (103.2°F), severe 'lead-pipe' muscle rigidity, and tachycardia.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: Patient C: BP 160/100, Temp 39.5°C, HR 128. Diaphoretic.

rows.text: Restlessness, pacing, and inability to sit still
Sudden, spastic contraction of the neck (Torticollis)
Muscle rigidity, hyperpyrexia, and autonomic instability

rationale.correct: Akathisia (r1) is the 'restlessness' and pacing. Acute Dystonia (r2) is the painful muscle contraction (Torticollis/Oculogyric crisis). NMS (r3) is a life-threatening emergency defined by lead-pipe rigidity and high fever. Tardive Dyskinesia (r4) is the long-term, irreversible involuntary movement of the face/tongue.
clinicalPearls: NMS triad: Fever, Rigidity, Autonomic Instability.
Benztropine (Cogentin) is the primary treatment for Acute Dystonia.
Akathisia is often mistaken for worsening psychosis; don't increase the antipsychotic!

questionTrap.trap: Thinking NMS is the same thing as Serotonin Syndrome.

mnemonic.title: The EPS Order
mnemonic.expansion: ADAL: Acute Dystonia (Hours), Akathisia (Days), Late TD (Months/Years).
